papers.title: The Occurrence Rate of Nearby Planetary Companions to Hot Jupiters
papers.abstract: Of the > 500 confirmed transiting hot jupiters and approximately 2000 additional candidates today, only ten are known to have nearby companion planets. The survival of nearby companions means that these hot jupiters cannot have migrated to their present location via dynamically disruptive high-eccentricity migration but instead have undergone disk migration or formed in situ. The occurrence rate for these nearby companions, therefore, constrains the relative efficiency of different hot jupiter formation pathways. Here, we perform a uniform box least-squares search for nearby transiting companions to hot jupiters in the first five years of TESS data. Accounting for observational completeness and detection efficiency, we arrive at an occurrence rate of (7.6 (+5.5/-3.8))\%, which is a lower limit on the fraction of hot jupiters that underwent disk migration or in situ formation. Comparing this rate with that derived from transit-timing variation searches suggests that hot jupiters are likely mostly aligned with their nearby companions, but their apparently higher incidence of grazing transits may point to a slight preferential misalignment. We also synthesize evidence that hot jupiters with nearby companions may have cold companions at a rate similar to that of other hot jupiters. Comprehensive transit, radial velocity, and stellar obliquity measurements in hot jupiter systems with nearby companions will be necessary to fully account for the relative prevalence of proposed hot jupiter formation pathways.
papers.summary:
**Why It Matters**

Hot Jupiters are some of the most extreme worlds we've discovered‚Äîmassive gas giants that orbit incredibly close to their stars, completing a full year in just a few days. These scorching worlds shouldn't exist where we find them, since planets this large typically form much farther from their stars. Understanding how hot Jupiters ended up in such unlikely places is one of astronomy's biggest puzzles, and solving it could reveal fundamental truths about how planetary systems throughout the galaxy come to be. The key lies in studying their neighboring planets, which act like cosmic breadcrumbs telling the story of each system's violent or gentle past.

**What They Did**

The researchers analyzed five years of data from TESS, NASA's planet-hunting space telescope, which watches for the tiny dips in starlight that occur when planets pass in front of their stars. They focused specifically on stars already known to host hot Jupiters and searched for signs of additional planets orbiting nearby. Think of it like being a detective examining a crime scene‚Äîin this case, looking for witnesses (companion planets) that survived whatever dramatic events moved these gas giants so close to their stars. The team then carefully calculated how often such companion planets actually exist, accounting for the limitations of their detection methods.

**Key Findings**

The study found that roughly 8% of hot Jupiters have nearby planetary companions‚Äîa surprisingly small number that represents only ten confirmed cases out of hundreds of known hot Jupiter systems. This low occurrence rate suggests that most hot Jupiters likely experienced violent migrations that would have ejected or destroyed any neighboring worlds. The researchers also discovered that these rare companion planets tend to orbit in the same plane as their hot Jupiter neighbors, indicating relatively peaceful coexistence.

**Looking Forward**

This research provides crucial evidence that there are at least two distinct pathways for creating hot Jupiters: a gentle process that preserves companion planets, and a more destructive process that eliminates them. As astronomers discover more of these systems and study them in greater detail, we'll gain deeper insights into the chaotic early lives of planetary systems‚Äîincluding our own solar system's formation billions of years ago.

papers.title: Analytic Modeling of Tidally Locked Rocky Planet Atmospheres Across Dynamical Regimes
papers.abstract: We present a new first-principles analytic approach to interpreting eclipses and phase curves of rocky planets. Observations with JWST have reported nondetections of atmospheres around the majority of hot rocky planets orbiting M dwarfs. However, most of these "bare rock" inferences are based on models that are ill-suited to many currently observable planets, as they were developed for use on cooler, slower-rotating bodies. In particular, these models rely on the weak temperature gradient assumption, in which rotation is neglected and temperature gradients can be simply related to wind speeds. We find that this assumption may not be valid for over 40% of terrestrials observed with JWST, including TRAPPIST-1b, GJ 367b, and TOI-2445b. Our simple new four-box model does not rely on this assumption, and instead allows the heat transport efficiency to be specified or follow scalings derived herein. This method is fast, interpretable, physically motivated, reproduces previous general circulation model results, and can be used as a starting point for more detailed modeling. We observe that the longitudinal temperature structure of tidally locked terrestrials depends strongly on the atmospheric circulation. Considering the applicable range of atmospheric dynamical regimes, we find that a given planet's nightside temperature can plausibly vary by 100s of Kelvin (from detectable to undetectable). Furthermore, a planet's dayside energy balance can display complex behavior, with degeneracies between surface pressure and dayside temperature. Illustrating an application to observations, we find that assumptions about atmospheric dynamics and longitudinal temperature structure can bias atmospheric constraints at the order-of-magnitude level.
papers.summary:
**Why It Matters**

Imagine trying to determine if a distant house has heating by measuring its temperature from miles away‚Äîthat's essentially what astronomers face when studying planets around other stars. With the James Webb Space Telescope now peering at rocky planets similar to Earth, we're getting our first real glimpse of what these distant worlds might be like. But here's the problem: many of these planets appear to be "bare rock" with no atmospheres at all. This research suggests we might be drawing the wrong conclusions because we're using the wrong tools to interpret what we're seeing. Understanding whether rocky planets can hold onto their atmospheres is crucial for determining if any of them could potentially support life.

**What They Did**

The researchers developed a new mathematical model to better understand the climates of tidally locked planets‚Äîworlds where one side always faces their star (like how one side of the Moon always faces Earth). Previous models made simplifying assumptions that work well for slowly rotating planets like Earth, but break down for these extreme worlds that whip around their stars in just days or weeks. Instead of relying on these outdated assumptions, the team created a "four-box model" that treats the planet like four connected regions and allows heat to move between them more realistically. They tested this model against computer simulations and observations from the James Webb Space Telescope.

**Key Findings**

The results were striking: a planet's nightside temperature could vary by hundreds of degrees Kelvin depending on how efficiently its atmosphere transports heat‚Äîthe difference between being detectable by our telescopes or completely invisible. The team found that over 40% of rocky planets observed by James Webb, including several in the famous TRAPPIST-1 system, might be misunderstood by current models. Most surprisingly, atmospheric assumptions could throw off temperature estimates by order-of-magnitude levels, meaning some planets we've labeled as "airless" might actually have substantial atmospheres.

**Looking Forward**

This research could revolutionize how we interpret observations of rocky exoplanets. Rather than hastily concluding that most hot rocky planets are bare, astronomers now have better tools to detect thin atmospheres that might have been missed. This is particularly exciting for studying potentially habitable worlds, as it suggests atmospheres might survive in places we didn't expect‚Äîexpanding our search for planets that could support life.

papers.title: BOWIE-ALIGN: Sub-solar C/O ratio and metallicity atmosphere of the misaligned hot Jupiter HAT-P-30b
papers.abstract: We present the JWST NIRSpec/G395H transmission spectrum of the misaligned hot Jupiter HAT-P-30b from 2.8--5.2 Œºm as part of the BOWIE-ALIGN survey, a comparative survey designed to probe the link between planet formation and atmospheric composition in samples of misaligned and aligned hot Jupiters orbiting F-type stars. Through independent data reductions and retrieval analyses, we find evidence for absorption features of H_2O and CO_2 in the atmosphere of HAT-P-30b. Our retrieved abundances are consistent with equilibrium chemistry, from which we infer a sub-solar C/O ratio (0.16--0.45), and sub-solar and sub-stellar metallicity (0.2--0.8√ósolar, compared to a stellar metallicity of 1.1--1.6√ósolar), with muted spectral features. This composition challenges formation models of continuous migration and accretion within a steady disc of stellar metallicity, and could be the result of low C/O ratio gas accretion within the water ice line, low metallicity accretion due to the trapping of volatiles further out in the disc, or the combined accretion of low metallicity gas and carbon-poor solids.
papers.summary:
**Why It Matters**

Imagine trying to solve a cosmic mystery: how do planets form around distant stars? Scientists are getting closer to cracking this puzzle by studying the atmospheres of "hot Jupiters"‚Äîmassive planets that orbit extremely close to their stars. These scorching worlds act like time capsules, preserving clues about their birth billions of years ago. By analyzing what gases make up their atmospheres, astronomers can work backwards to understand where and how these planets originally formed, then trace their dramatic journey to their current positions. This research helps us understand not just alien worlds, but the fundamental processes that shape planetary systems throughout our galaxy.

**What They Did**

Researchers used the James Webb Space Telescope, humanity's most powerful space observatory, to peer into the atmosphere of a distant planet called HAT-P-30b. This hot Jupiter is located about 700 light-years away and has an unusual characteristic‚Äîit orbits its star at a tilted angle, like a spinning top that's been knocked askew. The team captured starlight filtering through the planet's atmosphere as it passed in front of its star, similar to how we might study a soap bubble by looking at light shining through it. By breaking this light into its component colors and examining which wavelengths were absorbed, they could identify specific molecules floating in the planet's atmospheric layers.

**Key Findings**

The atmosphere contains water vapor and carbon dioxide, but in unexpected proportions. The planet has a surprisingly low ratio of carbon to oxygen‚Äîbetween 16% and 45% of what we see in our Sun‚Äîand overall contains fewer heavy elements than expected. Most intriguingly, the planet's atmosphere is actually less metal-rich than its host star, which is quite unusual since planets typically form from the same material as their stars.

**Looking Forward**

These findings challenge current theories about how hot Jupiters form and migrate. The unusual atmospheric composition suggests this planet may have formed in the cooler, outer regions of its solar system before spiraling inward, gathering specific types of materials along the way. This research is part of a larger survey comparing tilted and aligned hot Jupiters, which could revolutionize our understanding of planetary formation and the incredible journeys these worlds take through space.

papers.title: Architectures of Exoplanetary Systems. IV: A Multi-planet Model for Reproducing the Radius Valley and Intra-system Size Similarity of Planets around Kepler's FGK Dwarfs
papers.abstract: The Kepler-observed distribution of planet sizes have revealed two distinct patterns: (1) a radius valley separating super-Earths and sub-Neptunes and (2) a preference for intra-system size similarity. We present a new model for the exoplanet population observed by Kepler, which is a "hybrid" of a clustered multi-planet model in which the orbital architectures are set by the angular momentum deficit (AMD) stability (He et al. 2020; arXiv:2007.14473) and a joint mass-radius-period model involving envelope mass-loss driven by photoevaporation (Neil & Rogers 2020; arXiv:1911.03582). We find that the models that produce the deepest radius valleys have a primordial population of planets with initial radii peaking at ~ 2.1 R_‚äï, which is subsequently sculpted by photoevaporation into a bimodal distribution of final planet radii. The hybrid model requires strongly clustered initial planet masses in order to match the distributions of the size similarity metrics. Thus, the preference for intra-system radius similarity is well explained by a clustering in the primordial mass distribution. The hybrid model also naturally reproduces the observed radius cliff (steep drop-off beyond ~ 2.5 R_‚äï). Our hybrid model is the latest installment of the SysSim forward models, and is the first multi-planet model capable of simultaneously reproducing the observed radius valley and the intra-system size similarity patterns. We compute occurrence rates and fractions of stars with planets for a variety of planet types, and find that the occurrence of Venus and Earth-like planets drops by a factor of ~ 2-4 for the hybrid models compared to previous clustered models in which there is no envelope mass-loss.
papers.summary:
**Why It Matters**

When we look up at the night sky, one of humanity's most profound questions is whether Earth-like worlds exist around other stars. NASA's Kepler Space Telescope has discovered thousands of planets orbiting distant stars, revealing surprising patterns that challenge our understanding of how planetary systems form. This research tackles two major mysteries: why planets seem to come in preferred sizes with a conspicuous gap between them, and why planets within the same star system tend to be remarkably similar to each other‚Äîunlike our own solar system where tiny Mercury sits alongside giant Jupiter.

**What They Did**

The researchers created a sophisticated computer model that acts like a planetary system simulator. Think of it as a cosmic recipe book that starts with the "ingredients" of planet formation‚Äîdust, gas, and rocky cores around young stars‚Äîthen follows what happens over millions of years. Their model combines two key processes: how planets initially cluster together during formation, and how intense starlight later strips away the thick atmospheres of planets that venture too close to their host stars. By running thousands of simulations with different starting conditions, they could test which scenarios best match what Kepler actually observed in our galaxy.

**Key Findings**

The model reveals that planets originally formed with radii around 2.1 times Earth's size‚Äîbigger than our home planet but smaller than Neptune. Over time, stellar radiation sculpted this single population into two distinct groups: smaller "super-Earths" and larger "sub-Neptunes," creating the mysterious gap we observe today. The research also confirms that planets born in the same system start with very similar masses, explaining why they end up looking like siblings. Importantly, the model predicts that truly Earth-like and Venus-like worlds are 2-4 times rarer than previous estimates suggested.

**Looking Forward**

This breakthrough gives astronomers their first comprehensive framework for understanding planetary diversity across the galaxy. As next-generation telescopes like the James Webb Space Telescope examine these distant worlds in greater detail, this model will help predict which systems are most likely to harbor potentially habitable planets, guiding our search for life beyond Earth.

papers.title: Toward Reliable Interpretations of Small Exoplanet Compositions: Comparisons and Considerations of Equations of State and Materials Used in Common Rocky Planet Models
papers.abstract: The bulk compositions of small planets (R_p< 2 R_‚äï) are directly linked to their formation histories, making reliable compositional constraints imperative for testing models of planet formation and evolution. Because exoplanet interiors cannot be directly observed, their make-up must be inferred from mass-radius-composition models that link assumed stellar abundances to the direct observables: planetary mass and radius. There are a variety of such models in the literature, each adopting different equations of state (EOS) to describe the materials' properties at depth and varying assumptions about the minerals present within the planets. These EOS+mineral suites provide the foundations for compositional inferences, but they have not yet been systematically compared. In this work, we review several suites, with a detailed description of the basic structure, mineral physics, and materials within standard small planet models. We show that EOS+mineral suites predict planet densities whose differences are comparable to current observational uncertainties, which present a challenge for robustly interpreting and classifying small planets. We apply a powerful small-planet characterization framework, which illustrates that variations among EOS+mineral suites lead to inconsistent conclusions for both individual planets and sample-level demographics. Our results demonstrate the need for more careful considerations of the materials and EOS used in mass-radius-composition models, especially given the current focus on finding and characterizing potentially habitable rocky planets. We conclude with recommendations for best practices so that future interpretations of small planets and their formation are accurate and consistent.
papers.summary:
**Why It Matters**

Imagine trying to figure out what's inside a wrapped present just by weighing it and measuring its size. That's essentially what astronomers do when studying small, rocky planets beyond our solar system‚Äîcalled exoplanets. Understanding what these distant worlds are made of is crucial because their composition tells the story of how they formed billions of years ago. With thousands of these planets now discovered, and with the tantalizing possibility that some might harbor life, getting their makeup right has never been more important. But here's the problem: different scientific teams are using different methods to analyze the same planets, and they're reaching conflicting conclusions about what these worlds are actually made of.

**What They Did**

The researchers acted like scientific detectives, comparing the various "recipe books" that astronomers use to interpret exoplanet data. These recipe books contain mathematical descriptions of how different materials‚Äîlike iron, rock, and ice‚Äîbehave under the extreme pressures and temperatures found deep inside planets. Think of it like comparing different conversion charts that translate a planet's weight and size into its likely composition. The team gathered several of these widely-used recipe books and tested them on the same set of small planets to see if they would reach similar conclusions about what these worlds contain.

**Key Findings**

The results were troubling: the different recipe books gave conflicting answers about the same planets. The differences in predicted compositions were large enough to matter‚Äîcomparable to the uncertainties in our current measurements. This means that when one research team concludes a planet is mostly rocky while another says it's rich in water, both might be "right" according to their chosen methods. The researchers found that these disagreements affect not just individual planets, but our understanding of planet populations as a whole.

**Looking Forward**

This research serves as a wake-up call for the exoplanet community. As we enter an era of discovering potentially habitable worlds, astronomers need to standardize their analysis methods to ensure reliable results. The study provides a roadmap for developing better, more consistent approaches to studying these distant worlds, ultimately improving our ability to identify truly Earth-like planets in our cosmic neighborhood.

papers.title: JWST COMPASS: Insights into the Systematic Noise Properties of NIRSpec/G395H From a Uniform Reanalysis of Seven Transmission Spectra
papers.abstract: JWST has already observed near-infrared transmission spectra of over a dozen super-Earths and sub-Neptunes. While some observations have allowed astronomers to characterize sub-Neptunes in unprecedented detail, small feature amplitudes and poorly-understood systematics have led to ambiguous results for others. Using the first seven targets from the COMPASS program, which is currently surveying 12 small planet atmospheres using NIRSpec/G395H, we investigate these timeseries systematics. We implement a model that uses the principle components of the normalized pixel fluxes to account for variations in the shape and position of the spectral trace. We find that observations with a smaller number of groups-per-integration benefit most profoundly from the use of this model, and that systematics are particularly strong between 2.8 and 3.5 Œºm. Despite these systematics, pandexo is a relatively accurate predictor of the precision of the spectra, with real error bars on average 5\% larger in NRS1 and 12\% larger in NRS2 than predicted. We compute new limits on metallicity and opaque pressure level for each target and compare these to previous results from the COMPASS program. Next, we co-add spectra from multiple targets to reduce the effective noise in the combined spectra in hopes of detecting transmission features in common between the targets, but this exercise does not yield compelling evidence any signals. We find that a handful of additional transits are sufficient to break the degeneracy between metallicity and aerosols for the majority of our targets, pointing towards the possibility of unraveling the mysteries of these worlds with future allocations of JWST time.

**Why It Matters**

Imagine trying to study a firefly's glow while looking through a dirty, shifting window‚Äîthat's essentially the challenge astronomers face when studying the atmospheres of distant planets. The James Webb Space Telescope has opened an incredible new window into worlds beyond our solar system, particularly small planets similar in size to Earth and Neptune. Understanding these planets' atmospheres could help us learn how planets form, evolve, and potentially support life. But to unlock these secrets, scientists first need to understand and correct for the "noise" that interferes with their observations, much like cleaning that dirty window to see the firefly more clearly.

**What They Did**

papers.title: Discovery and characterisation of two exoplanets orbiting the metal-poor, solar-type star TOI-5788 with TESS, CHEOPS, and HARPS-N
papers.abstract: We present the discovery and characterisation of two transiting exoplanets orbiting the metal-poor, solar-type star TOI-5788. From our analysis of six TESS sectors and a dedicated CHEOPS programme, we identify an inner planet (TOI-5788~b; P = 6.340758¬±0.000030\,) with radius 1.528¬±0.075\,R_‚äï and an outer planet (TOI-5788~c; P = 16.213362¬±0.000026\,) with radius 2.272¬±0.039\,R_‚äï. We obtained 125 radial-velocity spectra from HARPS-N and constrain the masses of TOI-5788~b and~c as 3.72¬±0.94\,M_‚äï and 6.4¬±1.2\,M_‚äï, respectively. Although dynamical analyses indicate that a third planet could exist in a stable orbit between 8 and 14 days, we find no evidence of additional planets. Since the TOI-5788 system is one of the few systems with planets straddling the radius gap, and noting that there are even fewer such systems around metal poor stars, it is a promising system to constrain planet formation theories. We therefore model the interior structures of both planets. We find that TOI-5788~b is consistent with being a rocky planet with almost no envelope, or having an atmosphere of a high mean molecular weight. We find that TOI-5788~c is consistent with both gas-dwarf and water-world hypotheses of mini-Neptune formation. We model the atmospheric evolution history of both planets. Whilst both scenarios are consistent with the atmospheric evolution of TOI-5788~c, the gas-dwarf model is marginally preferred. The results of the atmospheric evolution analysis are not strongly dependent on stellar evolution. This makes the system a promising target to test internal structure and atmospheric evolution models.

**Why It Matters**

Imagine finding two siblings in space‚Äîone rocky like Earth, the other more like Neptune‚Äîorbiting around a star that's quite different from our Sun. That's exactly what astronomers have discovered with the TOI-5788 system, and it's helping us solve one of the biggest puzzles in planet formation. This star is "metal-poor," meaning it has fewer heavy elements than our Sun, yet it managed to create two fascinating worlds. Understanding how planets form around different types of stars gives us crucial insights into how common Earth-like worlds might be throughout the galaxy, and ultimately, how special our own solar system really is.

**What They Did**

The research team used three powerful space-based and ground-based telescopes working together like a cosmic detective squad. First, NASA's TESS satellite spotted tiny dips in starlight as the planets crossed in front of their star‚Äîthink of it like watching the shadow of a moth flying past a streetlight. The European CHEOPS mission provided additional observations to nail down the planets' sizes with precision. Finally, the HARPS-N instrument measured the subtle wobble these planets create in their star's motion as they orbit, allowing scientists to calculate their masses. It's like determining someone's weight by watching how much they make a seesaw tip.

The team discovered two remarkable worlds: TOI-5788 b, the inner planet, is about 1.5 times Earth's width and nearly four times its mass‚Äîmaking it a "super-Earth" that's likely rocky with little to no atmosphere. What makes this discovery special is that these planets straddle the mysterious "radius gap"‚Äîa size range where few planets are found, suggesting something dramatic happens during planet formation.

Scientists can now study whether mini-Neptunes like TOI-5788 c formed as gas-rich worlds or water-rich "ocean planets," and why some planets retain thick atmospheres while others lose them entirely. With future observations, this system could help us predict what types of planets form around the most common stars in our galaxy.

papers.title: Clouds and Chemistry Across the Brown Dwarf T-Y Sequence: Insights from JWST Atmospheric Retrievals
papers.abstract: The James Webb Space Telescope (JWST) offers exceptional spectral resolution and wavelength coverage, which are essential for studying the coldest brown dwarfs, particularly Y dwarfs. These objects are at the cold end of the sub-stellar sequence and exhibit atmospheric phenomena such as cloud formation, chemical disequilibrium, and radiative-convective coupling. We examine a curated sample of 22 late-T to Y dwarfs through Bayesian atmospheric retrieval (nested sampling) and supervised machine learning (random forests). Bayesian model comparison indicates that cloud-free models are generally favored for the hottest objects in the sample (T6-T8). Conversely, later-type dwarfs exhibit varying preferences, with both gray-cloud and cloud-free models providing comparable fits. The atmospheric parameters retrieved are consistent across the applied methodologies. Evidence of vertical mixing and disequilibrium chemistry is found in several objects; notably, the Y1 dwarf WISEPAJ1541-22 favors a gray cloud model and shows elevated abundances of both CO and CO2 compared to equilibrium chemistry calculations. As anticipated, the abundances of H2O, CH4, and NH3 increase with decreasing effective temperature over the T-Y sequence.
papers.summary:
**Why It Matters**

Imagine trying to understand Earth's weather by studying it from trillions of miles away‚Äîthat's essentially what astronomers do when they peer into the atmospheres of distant worlds. This research focuses on brown dwarfs, mysterious objects that are too small to be stars but too large to be planets. Think of them as "failed stars" that never quite ignited. The coldest brown dwarfs are surprisingly similar to giant planets like Jupiter, making them perfect laboratories for understanding atmospheric processes that occur on worlds beyond our solar system. By studying these objects, we're essentially getting a preview of what we might find when we examine the atmospheres of distant planets orbiting other stars.

**What They Did**

Scientists used the James Webb Space Telescope‚Äîour most powerful space observatory‚Äîto analyze the light from 22 extremely cold brown dwarfs. When these objects emit infrared light, different chemicals in their atmospheres absorb specific wavelengths, creating a unique fingerprint. It's like identifying ingredients in a soup by taste, except astronomers identify atmospheric components by analyzing light. The team used two complementary approaches: a statistical method called Bayesian analysis that weighs different atmospheric models against the data, and machine learning algorithms that can spot patterns humans might miss. This dual approach helped them determine whether these objects have cloudy or clear atmospheres and what chemicals are floating around in their skies.

**Key Findings**

The research revealed that atmospheric conditions change dramatically across different temperature ranges. The warmer brown dwarfs (still incredibly cold by our standards) tend to have clear, cloud-free atmospheres, while the coldest objects show mixed results‚Äîsome have clouds, others don't. Most intriguingly, the scientists found evidence of atmospheric mixing and chemical imbalances in several objects, particularly in an ultra-cool brown dwarf called WISEPAJ1541-22. This object showed unexpectedly high levels of both carbon monoxide and carbon dioxide, suggesting active atmospheric processes are stirring up chemicals that shouldn't coexist under normal conditions.

**Looking Forward**

These findings provide crucial insights for future exoplanet research. As we develop more sensitive instruments capable of analyzing the atmospheres of Earth-like planets around other stars, understanding atmospheric processes in these brown dwarf "test cases" will help us interpret what we find. The techniques pioneered here will be essential for determining whether distant worlds have the right atmospheric conditions to support life.

papers.title: Pre-computed aerosol extinction, scattering and asymmetry grids for scalable atmospheric retrievals
papers.abstract: The unprecedented wavelength coverage and sensitivity of the James Webb Space Telescope (JWST) permits to measure the absorption features of a wide range of condensate species from Silicates to Titan tholins. Atmospheric retrievals are uniquely suited to analyse these datasets and characterize the aerosols present in exoplanet atmospheres. However, including the optical properties of condensed particles within retrieval frameworks remains computationally expensive, limiting our ability to fully exploit JWST observations. In this work, we improve the computational efficiency and scaling behavior of aerosol models in atmospheric retrievals, enabling in-depth studies including multiple condensate species within practical time scales. Rather than computing the aerosol Mie coefficients for each sampled model, we pre-compute extinction efficiency (Qext), scattering efficiency (Qscat) and asymmetry parameter (g) grids for seven condensate species relevant in exoplanet atmospheres (Mg2SiO4 amorph sol - gel, MgSiO3 amorph glass, MgSiO3 amorph sol - gel, SiO2 alpha, SiO2 amorph, SiO and Titan tholins). The pre-computed Qext grids significantly reduce computation time between 1.4 and 17 times with negligible differences on the retrieved parameters. They also scale effortlessly with the number of aerosol species while maintaining the accuracy of cloud models. Thereby enabling more complex retrievals as well as broader population studies without increasing the overall error budget. The Qext, Qscat and g grids are freely available on Zenodo as well as a public TauREx plugin -TauREx-PCQ- that utilize them.
papers.summary:
**Why It Matters**

Imagine trying to figure out what clouds are made of by looking at them from hundreds of miles away‚Äîthat's essentially what scientists do when studying planets outside our solar system. The James Webb Space Telescope, our most powerful space observatory, can detect incredibly faint light from these distant worlds and reveal what's floating in their atmospheres. These alien clouds might contain exotic materials like liquid glass droplets or complex organic compounds similar to the hazy particles on Saturn's moon Titan. Understanding these atmospheric ingredients helps us learn how planets form and whether they might be suitable for life. But there's a catch: analyzing this data requires enormous amounts of computer processing power, often taking so long that scientists can only study a few planets at a time.

**What They Did**

The researchers tackled this computational bottleneck by creating a cosmic shortcut. Instead of having computers calculate the light-scattering properties of cloud particles from scratch every single time they analyze a planet, they pre-calculated these properties for seven important types of space dust and stored them in ready-to-use digital tables. Think of it like meal prepping for science‚Äîinstead of cooking from scratch each time you're hungry, you prepare ingredients in advance and just heat them up when needed. These materials include various forms of silicates (similar to volcanic glass) and organic compounds that could exist in alien atmospheres. The team then made these computational tools freely available to other researchers worldwide.

**Key Findings**

The pre-computed tables dramatically sped up the analysis process, making calculations between 1.4 and 17 times faster depending on the specific material being studied. Most importantly, this speed boost came with virtually no loss in accuracy‚Äîthe results were essentially identical to the slower, traditional methods. The system also scales efficiently, meaning scientists can now study multiple types of atmospheric particles simultaneously without exponentially increasing computation time.

**Looking Forward**

This breakthrough means astronomers can now conduct broader surveys of exoplanet atmospheres and study multiple worlds in the time it previously took to analyze just one. As James Webb continues discovering new planets, scientists will be better equipped to quickly identify patterns across different atmospheric compositions, potentially revealing new insights about planetary formation and the prevalence of potentially habitable worlds.

papers.title: Orbital Stability of Closely-Spaced Four-planet Systems
papers.abstract: We investigate the orbital dynamics of four-planet systems consisting of Earth-mass planets on initially-circular, coplanar orbits around a star of one solar mass. In our simulations, the innermost planet's semimajor axis is set at 1 AU, with subsequent semimajor axes spaced equally in terms of planets' mutual Hill radii. Several sets of initial planetary longitudes are investigated, with integrations continuing for up to 10^(10) orbits of the innermost planet, stopping if a pair of planets pass within 0.01 AU of each other or if a planet is ejected from the system. We find that the simulated lifetimes of four-planet systems follow the general trend of increasing exponentially with planetary spacing, as seen by previous studies of closely-spaced planets. Four-planet system lifetimes are intermediate between those of three- and five-planet systems and more similar to the latter. Moreover, as with five-planet systems, but in marked contrast to the three-planet case, no initial semimajor axes spacings are found to yield systems that survive several orders of magnitude longer than other similar spacings. First- and second-order mean-motion resonances (MMRs) between planets correlate with reductions in system lifetimes. Additionally, we find that third-order MMRs between planets on neighboring orbits also have a substantial, though smaller, destabilizing effect on systems very near resonance that otherwise would be very long-lived. Local extrema of system lifetimes as a function of planetary spacing occur at slightly smaller initial orbital separation for systems with planets initially at conjunction relative to those in which the planets begin on widely-separated longitudes. This shift is produced by the asymmetric mutual planetary perturbations as the planets separate in longitude from the initial aligned configuration that cause orbits to spread out in semimajor axis.
papers.summary:
**Why It Matters**

Astronomers have discovered thousands of planets orbiting other stars, and many of these worlds are packed surprisingly close together‚Äîmuch closer than the planets in our own solar system. Understanding whether these crowded planetary neighborhoods can remain stable over billions of years is crucial for determining where life might have a chance to evolve. If planets are constantly crashing into each other or getting flung out of their systems, any potential life would face an apocalyptic future. This research helps us predict which of the real exoplanet systems we've found might be stable enough to host life for the long haul.

**What They Did**

The researchers created computer simulations of imaginary solar systems, each containing four Earth-sized planets orbiting a Sun-like star. They placed these planets at different distances from each other and watched what happened over extremely long periods‚Äîup to 10 billion orbits, which represents many billions of years. Think of it like a cosmic video game where you can fast-forward through geological time scales. The scientists started some planets lined up like cars at a traffic light, while others began spread out around their orbits. They then tracked whether the planets would eventually collide, get ejected into deep space, or maintain stable orbits.

**Key Findings**

The simulations revealed that spacing is everything. When planets are placed farther apart, their systems survive exponentially longer‚Äîa small increase in distance can mean the difference between millions and billions of years of stability. Four-planet systems behaved more like five-planet systems than three-planet systems, suggesting that once you pack four or more worlds together, the gravitational chaos follows similar rules. Surprisingly, certain orbital arrangements called resonances‚Äîwhere planets complete their orbits in simple mathematical ratios‚Äîactually made systems less stable, not more.

**Looking Forward**

These findings provide astronomers with a roadmap for identifying which real exoplanet systems discovered by telescopes like Kepler and TESS are likely to be stable over cosmic time. This research brings us closer to answering one of humanity's most profound questions: where else in the universe might conditions remain stable enough for life to flourish?

papers.title: Is the high-energy environment of K2-18b special?
papers.abstract: K2-18b lies near the radius valley that separates super-Earths and sub-Neptunes, marking a key transitional regime in planetary and atmospheric composition. The system offers a valuable opportunity to study how M-dwarf high-energy stellar radiation influences atmospheric stability and the potential for sustaining volatile species, especially important in the context of the upcoming ELT and its ANDES spectrograph. This study characterizes the high-energy environment of K2-18 with X-ray observations from eROSITA, the soft X-ray instrument on the Spectrum-Roentgen-Gamma (SRG) mission, Chandra, and XMM-Newton. We derive a representative 0.2-2 keV X-ray flux with an APEC thermal plasma model fitted with the Bayesian X-ray Analysis (BXA). With the observed X-ray flux from the exoplanet host star, we estimate the photoevaporative mass loss of exoplanet K2-18b using the energy-limited model. In addition, we examine the thermal structure of the system based on a hydrodynamic model. In 100 ks XMM-Newton observation we identified K2-18 as a very faint X-ray source with F_X = 10^(-15) erg\,s^(-1)\,cm^(-2), with an activity level of (Lx/Lbol) ~ 10^(-5). A small flare has been detected during the observation. The planet is irradiated by an X-ray flux of F_(pl,X) = 12¬±3 erg\,s^(-1)\,cm^(-2). The X-ray flux measurement of K2-18 gives important limitations for atmospheric escape and photochemical modeling of its exoplanets. Despite its near orbit around an M-dwarf star, K2-18b's low activity level environment suggests that it can retain an atmosphere, supporting recent tentative detections of atmospheres.

**Why It Matters**

Imagine finding a planet that sits right on the boundary between two completely different types of worlds‚Äîone rocky like Earth, another puffy like a mini-Neptune. That's exactly what K2-18b represents, and it's recently made headlines for possibly having water vapor in its atmosphere. But here's the catch: this planet orbits an M-dwarf star, a type of red star known for unleashing powerful bursts of X-ray radiation that could strip away a planet's atmosphere entirely. Understanding whether K2-18b can actually keep its atmosphere intact is crucial for determining if such worlds could potentially harbor life. This research tackles a fundamental question: can planets around these common but temperamental stars maintain the atmospheric conditions necessary for habitability?

**What They Did**

The researchers turned their attention to K2-18, the host star, using three different space-based X-ray telescopes to measure how much high-energy radiation it pumps out. Think of it like using multiple specialized cameras to photograph the same lightning storm from different angles‚Äîeach telescope provided a unique view of the star's X-ray emissions. They spent 100,000 seconds (about 28 hours) carefully observing the star with one telescope, looking for both steady X-ray output and sudden flares. Using this data, they calculated how much X-ray radiation actually reaches the planet's atmosphere and then ran computer models to predict whether this radiation would cause the atmosphere to evaporate away into space.

**Key Findings**

Surprisingly, K2-18 turned out to be remarkably well-behaved for an M-dwarf star. The team found it emits X-rays at a very low level‚Äîabout 100,000 times dimmer in X-rays compared to its visible light output. They detected only one small flare during their entire observation period. The planet receives roughly 12 units of X-ray energy per second per square centimeter (a relatively gentle dose by cosmic standards). This low-energy environment suggests that K2-18b's atmosphere isn't being violently stripped away, contradicting expectations about planets around M-dwarf stars.

papers.title: Using observations of escaping H/He to constrain the atmospheric composition of sub-Neptunes
papers.abstract: The internal composition of sub-Neptunes remains a prominent unresolved question in exoplanetary science. We present a technique to place constraints on envelope mean molecular weight that utilises observations of escaping hydrogen or helium exospheres. This method is based on a simple timescale argument, which states that sub-Neptunes require a sufficiently large hydrogen or helium reservoir to explain on-going escape at their observed rates. This then naturally leads to an upper limit on atmospheric mean molecular weight. We apply this technique to archetypal sub-Neptunes, namely GJ-436 b, TOI-776 b and TOI-776 c, which have all been observed to be losing significant hydrogen content as well as relatively featureless transit spectra when observed with JWST. Combining constraints from atmospheric escape and transit spectroscopy in the case of TOI-776 c allows us to tentatively rule out the high mean molecular weight scenario, pointing towards a low mean molecular weight atmosphere with high-altitude aerosols muting spectral features in the infra-red. If such a detection is robust, we infer a hydrogen-rich envelope mass fraction of f_env = -1.67¬±0.78, which is inconsistent with the hycean scenario at the ~ 4œÉ level. This latter result requires further observational follow-up to confirm.

**Why It Matters**

Imagine trying to figure out what's inside a wrapped gift just by watching steam escape from it. That's essentially what astronomers are doing with a mysterious class of planets called sub-Neptunes‚Äîworlds larger than Earth but smaller than Neptune that are surprisingly common throughout our galaxy, yet completely absent from our own solar system. Understanding what these alien worlds are made of is crucial because they represent the most abundant type of planet we've discovered so far. Are they rocky planets with thick atmospheres, or mini gas giants? The answer could reshape our understanding of how planetary systems form and evolve.

**What They Did**

The researchers developed a clever detective technique by studying hydrogen and helium gas streaming away from these planets into space‚Äîlike observing steam rising from a hot cup of coffee. When planets lose atmosphere to space, they need a large reservoir of light gases to sustain this escape over long periods. The team used this principle as a cosmic scale: if a planet is losing gas at the rates we observe, it must contain enough hydrogen and helium to keep this process going. They then applied this method to several well-studied sub-Neptunes, including planets orbiting stars called GJ-436, TOI-776, and the intriguing world K2-18 b, which some scientists thought might be an ocean planet with a habitable environment.

papers.title: A Multi-Wavelength Study of Comet C/2022 E3 (ZTF): Complementary ALMA and JWST Investigations of Water and Methanol in Cometary Comae
papers.abstract: Long-period comets, which are often considered to be representative of material in the protoplanetary disk that formed the Solar System, are ideal to investigate the question of chemical inheritance in astronomy. Determining the chemistry of comets, both individually and as a population, has become of great importance in comparative studies against sources representative of evolutionary precursors to planetary systems. Contemporaneous observations of long-period comet C/2022 E3 (ZTF) were obtained with the JWST and the Atacama Large Millimeter/submillimeter Array (ALMA) in early 2023 March. This work focuses on CH3OH measurements from both ALMA and JWST as well as H2O measurements from JWST. Radiative transfer modeling of CH3OH and H2O was performed to investigate spatial variations in rotational temperature, column density, and production rates, as well as a comparison of derived values between the two telescopes. Most of the spatial distributions of the modeled values are centrally peaked, and the modeled values from JWST are all within the error bars of the average values from ALMA. C/2022 E3 (ZTF) also displays an enhancement in modeled rotational temperature in the anti-Sunward direction that is shown to be statistically significant. Based on non-LTE radiative transfer modeling, the declining H2O rotational temperatures as a function of nucleocentric distance observed by JWST can be explained primarily as a result of rotational line cooling. The values derived in this work are in general agreement with single-dish millimeter-wave observations.
papers.summary:
**Why It Matters**

Comets are like cosmic time capsules, preserving the original ingredients that formed our solar system 4.6 billion years ago. When scientists study these ancient wanderers, they're essentially reading a recipe book from the birth of planets. Comet C/2022 E3 (ZTF), which visited our inner solar system in early 2023, offered researchers a rare opportunity to peer into this primordial chemistry using humanity's most powerful space telescopes. Understanding what comets are made of helps us piece together how Earth got its water and organic compounds‚Äîand potentially, how life itself began.

**What They Did**

Scientists pointed two of our most advanced telescopes at this visiting comet: the James Webb Space Telescope (JWST), floating in space, and the Atacama Large Millimeter Array (ALMA), a collection of radio dishes high in Chile's desert. Think of it like using two different types of cameras to photograph the same subject‚Äîeach telescope "sees" different wavelengths of light that reveal different chemicals. They focused on detecting water and methanol (a simple alcohol) in the comet's glowing tail, called the coma. By analyzing how these molecules absorb and emit light, researchers could map their temperatures and concentrations like taking the comet's chemical fingerprint.

**Key Findings**

The team discovered that both water and methanol were most concentrated near the comet's center, as expected, but they also found something intriguing: the side of the comet facing away from the Sun was noticeably warmer than other regions. The measurements from both telescopes matched remarkably well, confirming their accuracy. As they tracked these molecules farther from the comet's core, they watched the water molecules cool down‚Äîlike watching your breath dissipate and cool in winter air.

**Looking Forward**

While this study focused on our own solar system, it's building crucial groundwork for exoplanet research. By understanding the chemical signatures of comets in our cosmic backyard, scientists are developing the tools and knowledge needed to identify similar processes around other stars, potentially revealing how common Earth-like chemistry might be throughout the universe.

papers.title: The PAIRS project: a global formation model for planets in binaries. I. Effect of disc truncation on the growth of S-type planets
papers.abstract: Binary stars are as common as single stars. The number of detected planets orbiting binaries is rapidly increasing thanks to the synergy between transit surveys, Gaia and high-resolution direct imaging campaigns. However, global planet formation models around binary stars are still underdeveloped, which limits the theoretical understanding of planets orbiting binary star systems. Hereby we introduce the PAIRS project, which aims at building a global planet formation model for planets in binaries, and to produce planet populations synthesis to statistically compare theory and observations. In this first paper, we present the adaptation of the circumstellar disc to simulate the formation of S-type planets. The presence of a secondary star tidally truncates and heats the outer part of the circumprimary disc (and vice-versa for the circumsecondary disc), limiting the material to form planets. We implement and quantify this effect for a range of binary parameters by adapting the Bern Model of planet formation in its pebble-based form and for in-situ planet growth. We find that the disc truncation has a strong impact on reducing the pebble supply for core growth, steadily suppressing planet formation for binary separations below 160 au, when considering all the formed planets more massive than Mars. We find as well that S-type planets tend to form close to the central star with respect to the binary separation and disc truncation radius. Our newly developed model will be the basis of future S-type planet population synthesis studies.
papers.summary:
**Why It Matters**

When we think of planets like Earth, we picture them orbiting a single star like our Sun. But here's a cosmic plot twist: about half of all stars in our galaxy actually come in pairs, dancing around each other in what astronomers call binary star systems. As our planet-hunting telescopes get better, we're discovering more and more worlds orbiting these stellar duos. Yet scientists have struggled to understand how planets actually form in these crowded cosmic neighborhoods. This research tackles that puzzle, helping us understand whether Earth-like worlds could exist in the most common type of star system in our galaxy‚Äîand what that might mean for life beyond our solar system.

**What They Did**

The researchers created a sophisticated computer model to simulate how planets grow around binary stars, focusing on "S-type" planets‚Äîworlds that orbit just one star in the pair, like the fictional planet Tatooine from Star Wars (though Tatooine actually orbits both stars). Think of it like modeling how a garden grows when there's a neighbor's house casting shade and creating wind‚Äîthe second star disrupts the disk of dust and gas around the first star, much like that neighbor affects growing conditions. The team used something called the Bern Model, adapting it to account for how the second star truncates (cuts short) and heats up the planet-forming disk, limiting the raw materials available for building worlds.

**Key Findings**

The results reveal just how dramatically a stellar companion can crash the planet-formation party. When the two stars are closer than 160 astronomical units apart (about four times the distance from our Sun to Pluto), planet formation gets seriously hampered. The second star essentially steals building materials‚Äîtiny particles called pebbles that would normally clump together to form planetary cores. The closer the stellar pair, the more severe this cosmic interference becomes. Interestingly, the planets that do manage to form tend to huddle close to their host star, staying as far as possible from the disruptive influence of the stellar neighbor.

**Looking Forward**

This breakthrough model opens the door to predicting what kinds of planet populations we should expect to find around binary stars. As space missions like TESS and future telescopes discover more of these worlds, scientists will finally have a theoretical framework to make sense of the observations and determine whether planets in binary systems could harbor the conditions necessary for life.

papers.title: A Joint Mass-Radius-Period Distribution of Exoplanets
papers.abstract: The radius-period distribution of exoplanets has been characterized by the Kepler survey, and the empirical mass-radius relation by the subset of Kepler planets with mass measurements. We combine the two in order to constrain the joint mass-radius-period distribution of Kepler transiting planets. We employ hierarchical Bayesian modeling and mixture models to formulate four models with varying complexity and fit these models to the data. We find that the most complex models that treat planets with significant gaseous envelopes, evaporated core planets, and intrinsically rocky planets as three separate populations are preferred by the data and provide the best fit to the observed distribution of Kepler planets. We use these models to calculate occurrence rates of planets in different regimes and to predict masses of Kepler planets, revealing the model dependent nature of both. When using models with envelope mass loss to calculate Œ∑_‚äï, we find nearly an order of magnitude drop, indicating that many Earth-like planets discovered with Kepler may be evaporated cores which do not extrapolate out to higher orbital periods. This work provides a framework for higher-dimensional studies of planet occurrence and for using mixture models to incorporate different theoretical populations of planets.

**Why It Matters**

Imagine trying to understand all the different types of cars on Earth by only looking at a small parking lot. That's essentially the challenge astronomers face when studying planets beyond our solar system. The Kepler Space Telescope has discovered thousands of these "exoplanets," but we're still piecing together the big picture: what types of planets are most common, and how do they form and evolve? This research tackles one of astronomy's most fundamental questions‚Äîare Earth-like worlds rare cosmic accidents, or are they abundant throughout the galaxy? The answer could reshape our understanding of how common life might be in the universe.

**What They Did**

The researchers combined two key pieces of information about exoplanets: how big they are (radius) and how heavy they are (mass), along with how long they take to orbit their stars (period). Think of it like creating a comprehensive catalog that lists the height, weight, and running speed of every athlete in multiple sports. They used advanced statistical techniques‚Äîessentially sophisticated pattern-recognition software‚Äîto group planets into different "families" based on their shared characteristics. This approach is similar to how a zoologist might classify animals into species by looking at multiple traits simultaneously rather than just one feature at a time.

**Key Findings**

The analysis revealed that planets fall into three distinct groups, like different breeds of dogs that initially look similar. There are rocky planets (like Earth), planets with thick gaseous atmospheres, and a surprising third category: planets that used to have thick atmospheres but lost them over time, leaving behind just their rocky cores. This discovery suggests that many planets we thought were naturally Earth-sized might actually be "stripped" versions of larger worlds. The researchers found that when accounting for this atmospheric loss, the number of truly Earth-like planets drops by nearly ten times‚Äîa dramatic revision to previous estimates.

**Looking Forward**

This research provides a new framework for understanding planetary diversity and evolution. It suggests that the galaxy might be less populated with Earth-twins than we hoped, but it also reveals that planetary systems are more dynamic than previously thought, with atmospheres being lost and gained over billions of years. This work will help guide future space missions in their search for potentially habitable worlds and refine our estimates for how common life-supporting planets might be.

papers.title: The ALMA survey to Resolve exoKuiper belt Substructures (ARKS). X. Interpreting the peculiar dust rings around HD 131835
papers.abstract: Dusty discs detected around main-sequence stars are thought to be signs of planetesimal belts in which the dust distribution is shaped by collisional and dynamical processes, including interactions with gas if present. The debris disc around the young A-type star HD 131835 is composed of two dust rings at ~65 au and ~100 au, a third unconstrained innermost component, and a gaseous component centred at ~65 au. New ALMA observations show that the inner of the two dust rings is brighter than the outer one, in contrast with previous observations in scattered light. We explore two scenarios that could explain these observations: the two dust rings might represent distinct planetesimal belts with different collisional properties, or only the inner ring might contain planetesimals while the outer ring consists entirely of dust that has migrated outwards due to gas drag. To explore the first scenario, we employed a state-of-the-art collisional evolution code. To test the second scenario, we used a simple dynamical model of dust grain evolution in an optically thin gaseous disc. Collisional models of two planetesimal belts cannot fully reproduce the observations by only varying their dynamical excitation, and matching the data through a different material strength requires an extreme difference in dust composition. The gas-driven scenario can reproduce the location of the outer ring and the brightness ratio of the two rings from scattered light observations, but the resulting outer ring is too faint overall in both scattered light and sub-millimetre emission. The dust rings in HD 131835 could be produced from two planetesimal belts, although how these belts would attain the required extremely different properties needs to be explained. The dust-gas interaction is a plausible alternative explanation and deserves further study using a more comprehensive model.
papers.summary:
**Why It Matters**

When astronomers discover planets orbiting other stars, they're often looking at mature solar systems. But to truly understand how planets form, we need to catch star systems in the act‚Äîwhile they're still building their planetary families. That's exactly what researchers have done with HD 131835, a young star surrounded by dusty rings that might be the birthplace of future planets. These cosmic construction zones, filled with colliding rocks and swirling dust, offer us a window into how our own solar system might have looked billions of years ago. By studying these dusty discs, we can piece together the story of planetary birth and understand why some star systems end up with rocky planets like Earth while others develop gas giants or remain barren.

**What They Did**

The research team used the powerful ALMA telescope array in Chile to peer through space at HD 131835, a star about 400 light-years away that's roughly twice as massive as our Sun. They discovered something puzzling: two distinct rings of dust circling the star, one at about 65 times the Earth-Sun distance and another at 100 times that distance. What made this discovery strange was that the inner ring appeared brighter than expected compared to previous observations. To solve this mystery, the scientists ran two different computer simulations. The first modeled what would happen if both rings contained rocky debris constantly smashing together, like cosmic demolition zones. The second explored whether gas in the system might be pushing dust outward from the inner ring to create the outer one.

**Key Findings**

The team's detective work revealed that this star system doesn't behave like a typical dusty disc. The inner dust ring burns brighter than the outer one when viewed through ALMA's sub-millimeter vision, but previous observations using scattered light showed the opposite pattern. Neither of their proposed explanations perfectly matched what they observed. The collision scenario would require the two rings to be made of dramatically different materials‚Äîso different it seems almost impossible. The gas-pushing-dust scenario could explain where the outer ring sits and why it appears dimmer, but it predicts the ring should be much fainter overall than what they actually see.

**Looking Forward**

This cosmic puzzle suggests that planet-forming discs are far more complex and varied than scientists previously thought. HD 131835 might represent a completely new type of planetary construction zone that challenges our current understanding of how dust and gas interact around young stars. Future observations with even more powerful telescopes could help astronomers determine whether this system is a rare oddball or represents a common stage in planetary system evolution that we've simply missed before. Understanding these dusty rings better will ultimately help us predict what kinds of planets might form around different types of stars‚Äîand perhaps even help us understand why Earth turned out to be such a perfect home for life.

papers.title: The ALMA survey to Resolve exoKuiper belt Substructures (ARKS) V: Comparison between scattered light and thermal emission
papers.abstract: Debris discs are analogues to our own Kuiper belt around main-sequence stars and are therefore referred to as exoKuiper belts. They have been resolved at high angular resolution at wavelengths spanning the optical to the submillimetre-millimetre regime. Short wavelengths probe the light scattered by such discs, which is dominated by micron-sized dust particles, while millimetre wavelengths probe the thermal emission of millimetre-sized particles. Determining differences in the dust distribution between millimetre- and micron-sized dust is fundamental to revealing the dynamical processes affecting the dust in debris discs. We aim to compare the scattered light from the discs of the ALMA survey to Resolve exoKuiper belt Substructures (ARKS) with the thermal emission probed by ALMA. We focus on the radial distribution of the dust. We used high-contrast scattered light observations obtained with VLT/SPHERE, GPI, and the HST to uniformly study the dust distribution in those systems and compare it to the dust distribution extracted from the ALMA observations carried out in the course of the ARKS project. We also set constraints on the presence of planets by using these high-contrast images combined with exoplanet evolutionary models. 15 of the 24 discs comprising the ARKS sample are detected in scattered light, with TYC9340-437-1 being imaged for the first time at near-infrared wavelengths. For 6 of those 15 discs, the dust surface density seen in scattered light peaks farther out compared to that observed with ALMA. These 6 discs except one are known to also host cold CO gas. Conversely, the systems without significant offsets are not known to host gas, except one. This observational study suggests that the presence of gas in debris discs may affect the small and large grains differently, pushing the small dust to greater distances where the gas is less abundant.
papers.summary:
**Why It Matters**

Imagine if we could peer into other star systems and see cosmic debris fields similar to the icy region beyond Neptune in our own solar system. That's exactly what astronomers are doing when they study "debris discs"‚Äîthe leftover material orbiting distant stars that represents alien versions of our Kuiper Belt. These cosmic junkyards aren't just space curiosities; they're treasure troves of information about how planetary systems form and evolve. By studying the dust and debris swirling around other stars, we can better understand the forces that shaped our own cosmic neighborhood billions of years ago, and potentially discover hidden planets that are stirring up the debris.

**What They Did**

Researchers used a clever detective approach, studying the same debris discs with different types of "space eyes" to see what secrets they might reveal. Think of it like examining a dusty room with both a flashlight and a thermal camera‚Äîeach tool shows you different things. They used powerful telescopes to capture light reflected off tiny dust particles (like seeing dust motes in sunlight), and also used radio telescopes to detect heat given off by larger pebble-sized chunks. By comparing these two views across 24 different star systems, they could map where different sizes of debris were located and see if the patterns matched up or told different stories.

**Key Findings**

The results were surprising: in 6 out of 15 systems where both types of dust could be seen, the smaller particles were scattered much farther from their stars than the larger chunks‚Äîlike finding that powder from a demolished building had blown much farther than the rubble. Even more intriguingly, nearly all of these mismatched systems also contained gas, while the systems where small and large debris stayed together were mostly gas-free. This suggests that gas in these debris discs acts like a cosmic wind, pushing lightweight dust particles to the outer edges while leaving heavier material closer in.

**Looking Forward**

These findings could revolutionize how we search for planets around other stars. Gas-filled debris discs might be cosmic signposts pointing to planetary systems in the making, or indicating invisible planets whose gravity influences how dust and gas move through space. This research brings us closer to understanding the messy, dynamic process of planetary system evolution‚Äîand perhaps finding more worlds like our own.

papers.title: Turbulence Can Persist in the Inner Regions of Weakly-Ionized Planet Forming Disks
papers.abstract: Identifying the mechanisms responsible for angular momentum transport in protoplanetary disks, and the extent to which those mechanisms produce turbulence, is a crucial problem in understanding planet formation. The bulk of the gas in protoplanetary disks is weakly ionized, which leads to the emergence of three non-ideal effects, Ohmic diffusion, ambipolar diffusion, and the Hall effect. These low-ionization processes can in some cases suppress turbulence driven by the magnetorotational instability (MRI). However, it has recently been shown that these non-ideal terms can also affect the dynamics of the gas in fundamentally different ways than simple diffusion. In order to further study the role of low-ionization on disk gas dynamics, we carry out a 3D local shearing box simulation with both Ohmic diffusion and ambipolar diffusion and an additional simulation with the Hall effect included. The strength of each non-ideal term, when present, is representative of gas at a radius of 5 AU in a realistic protoplanetary disk. We find the Hall effect increases the saturation strength of the magnetic field, but does not necessarily drive turbulence, consistent with previous work. However, interactions between ambipolar diffusion and the Keplerian shear lead to the ambipolar diffusion shear instability (ADSI), which can drive the initial growth, not damping, of magnetic perturbations. To our knowledge, this is the first work that explicitly demonstrates the viability of the ADSI in the non-linear regime within protoplanetary disks. At later times in the disk, the MRI (reduced in strength by ambipolar-diffusion), may also be present in regions of weak magnetic field between strong concentrations of vertical magnetic flux and sustain turbulence locally in protoplanetary disks.
papers.summary:
**Why It Matters**

Picture a cosmic construction zone where planets are being built from scratch. These "planet-forming disks" are spinning clouds of gas and dust that surround young stars, and they're the birthplaces of every planet in the universe‚Äîincluding the thousands of exoplanets we've discovered orbiting other stars. But there's a fundamental mystery: how does the material in these disks move around and clump together to actually form planets? Understanding this process is crucial because it tells us not only how our own solar system came to be, but also why exoplanetary systems can look so dramatically different from ours. Some have giant planets orbiting closer to their stars than Mercury does to our Sun, while others have Earth-like worlds in completely unexpected arrangements.

**What They Did**

The researchers used powerful computer simulations to model a slice of a planet-forming disk, like studying a small section of a spinning pizza to understand how the whole thing behaves. They focused on conditions similar to what you'd find about 5 astronomical units from a young star‚Äîroughly where Jupiter sits in our solar system. The key was examining how the gas behaves when it's only weakly electrified (ionized), which is the normal state for most of the material in these disks. They ran their virtual experiments twice: once including two important physical effects called Ohmic diffusion and ambipolar diffusion, and once adding a third effect called the Hall effect.

**Key Findings**

The team discovered that these weakly-ionized conditions don't just calm things down as previously thought‚Äîthey can actually create their own form of turbulence. Specifically, they found that ambipolar diffusion combined with the disk's rotation can trigger something called the "ambipolar diffusion shear instability," which makes the gas churn and mix rather than settle into smooth layers. This was the first time researchers demonstrated this effect working in realistic disk conditions. Additionally, they found that even when the main turbulence-driving mechanism (called magnetorotational instability) is weakened, pockets of turbulence can persist in regions between strong magnetic field concentrations.

**Looking Forward**

This research reshapes how we think about planet formation. Turbulence in these disks acts like a cosmic mixer, stirring up dust and gas in ways that directly affect how and where planets can form. The discovery that turbulence can persist even in the inner regions of these disks‚Äîwhere rocky planets like Earth typically form‚Äîsuggests that planet formation might be more dynamic and complex than our current models predict. This could help explain the incredible diversity of exoplanetary systems we observe and guide us toward better understanding which types of systems are most likely to harbor Earth-like worlds.

papers.title: The ALMA survey to Resolve exoKuiper belt Substructures (ARKS) I: Motivation, sample, data reduction, and results overview
papers.abstract: The outer regions of planetary systems host dusty debris discs analogous to the Kuiper belt (exoKuiper belts), which provide crucial constraints on planet formation and evolution processes. ALMA dust observations have revealed a great diversity, and that some belts contain CO gas, whose origin and implications are uncertain. Most of this progress, however, has been limited by low-resolution observations. We conducted the first ALMA large programme dedicated to debris discs: the ALMA survey to Resolve exoKuiper belt Substructures (ARKS). We selected the 24 most promising belts to constrain their detailed radial and vertical structure, and to characterise the gas content. We constrained the radial and vertical distribution of dust, as well as the presence of asymmetries. For a subset of six belts with CO gas, we constrained the gas distribution and kinematics. To interpret these observations, we used a wide range of dynamical models. The first ARKS results are presented as a series of ten papers. We discovered that up to 33% of our sample exhibits multiple dusty rings. For highly inclined belts, we found that non-Gaussian vertical distributions are common and are indicative of multiple dynamical populations. We also found that 10 of the 24 belts present asymmetries. We find that the CO gas is radially broader than the dust, but this could be an effect of optical depth. At least one system shows non-Keplerian kinematics due to strong pressure gradients, which may have triggered a vortex that trapped dust in an arc. Finally, we find evidence that the micron-sized grains may be affected by gas drag in gas rich systems. ARKS has revealed a great diversity of structures in exoKuiper belts that may arise when they are formed in protoplanetary discs or subsequently via interactions with planets and/or gas. We encourage the community to explore the reduced data and data products.
papers.summary:
**Why It Matters**

Imagine if alien astronomers looked at our solar system from far away‚Äîthey might spot the Kuiper Belt, that ring of icy debris beyond Neptune where Pluto lives. Now astronomers have found similar belts around other stars, called "exoKuiper belts," and they're like cosmic archaeology sites. These dusty rings tell us the story of how planets formed billions of years ago and how they've been reshaping their neighborhoods ever since. Understanding these distant debris discs helps us piece together not just how other worlds came to be, but also how common planetary systems like our own might be throughout the galaxy.

**What They Did**

Researchers used ALMA‚Äîa network of powerful radio telescopes in Chile‚Äîto take the most detailed pictures ever captured of 24 promising debris belts around other stars. Think of it like upgrading from a blurry cell phone camera to a high-definition telescope when trying to photograph distant mountains. They specifically chose the most interesting targets that previous, lower-quality observations had hinted might have complex structures. The team measured where dust particles were located, how they moved through space, and whether these belts contained gases like carbon monoxide. They also created computer models to help explain what forces might be sculpting these distant rings.

**Key Findings**

The results revealed that these cosmic debris belts are far more complex than anyone expected. About one-third of the belts contained multiple rings, like a cosmic record player with several tracks. Ten of the 24 systems showed lopsided, asymmetrical shapes‚Äîimagine a hula hoop that's been dented on one side. In systems tilted nearly edge-on from our perspective, the researchers found that dust doesn't always settle into neat, flat pancakes but instead forms more complicated three-dimensional structures. Most surprisingly, they discovered that in some systems, invisible planets or swirling gas vortices might be acting like cosmic shepherds, corralling dust into arcs and controlling how particles move.

**Looking Forward**

These discoveries suggest that planetary systems are dynamic, ever-changing environments where planets continue to influence their surroundings long after formation. The intricate structures could help astronomers identify hidden planets that are too faint to see directly but leave their gravitational fingerprints on surrounding debris. This research opens new avenues for understanding how planetary systems evolve and mature, ultimately helping us better understand our own solar system's history and the potential for finding Earth-like worlds elsewhere.
